utterances: I'm great.
And so, you know, it's October.
I went out, I decorated my house for, you know, the fall.
There are a lot of people focused on the election.
But black college grads are looking forward to something else.
What's that?
Homecoming season.
For anyone who went to an HBCU right about now is the time people go home for homecoming as it were.
Howard had their homecoming last weekend, Morehouse and Stillman Colleges convene this week in Atlanta.
And Natalie McNeal of The Root offered five ways to hype up the fun while reducing the cost of homecomings, since folks have a little bit less money to spend this year.
And we have the list on our blog.

And we took an informal poll, as we sometimes do, 55 percent of those responding said the halftimes show was their main focus at homecoming, 18 percent said the game itself was the main draw, and the rest chose the answer what game?
I'd rather be tailgating.
Yeah.
I think that if people were honest there might be more in that category.
But let's move along to General Colin Powell endorsing Senator Barack Obama.
What's the reaction on our blog?
Yeah, that's the most popular topic of the week.
Let's listen to a part of Powell's rational for his endorsement as told to Tom Brokaw of NBC's Meet the Press.
He has met the standard of being a successful president, being an exceptional president.
I think he is a transformational figure.
He is a new generation coming in to the world, on to the world stage, on the American stage and for that reason, I'll be voting for Senator Barack Obama.
So, the reaction.
On our blog, a reader named Glenda Alvin wrote, ""I think Powell's endorsement is too late to really matter.
Powell's a four-star general who decided not to run for president because of his wife's fears of assassination.
Obama ran in spite of those fears.
He does not need Powell now."" To which another reader named John J.
replied, ""Before his interview on Meet the Press I felt the same way.
I was disappointed that it wasn't coming soon enough, but he hit all the key points.

Transformational figure was the phrase that resonated with me."" And Audrey Lewis wrote ""any and all endorsements the Senator can get right now are greatly appreciated, because it ain't over till it's over.
All right.
What else do we have coming up for folks on Election Day?
Well, we've got an interactive map that breaks down the electoral standing right now.
And the national state races.
We have profiles of all the key figures.
We have insight from our political contributors, and we have posts from you each day, as we get close to November fourth.
Yeah.
It's the countdown.
Two weeks to go.
Less than two weeks.
I know.
Geoff thank you.
Thank you.
Geoffrey Bennett is the web producer for News & Notes and he joined me from our studios right here at NPR West.
From NPR News this is NEWS AND NOTES.
I'm Ed Gordon.
The headlines of late has been dominated by the fight for the future of New Orleans and the debate over immigration rights.
Here to discuss these topics and more are Marc Morial, president and CEO of National Urban League, and the Reverend Jessie Jackson, president of Rainbow Push Coalition.
I should note the first Monday of every month we're usually joined by Mr. Morial and Bruce Gordon head of the NAACP to discuss topics affecting the black community.
Bruce Gordon is traveling this week, so we're very happy to have the Reverend Jackson with us.
Gentlemen welcome.
Marc, let me start with you.
In talking about the fight over the future of New Orleans, obviously, a key seat will be that of the Mayor's office with the run off coming off with Landrieu and Nagin.
How do you see things to this point?
I think it's a highly competitive race.
One of the things that continues to concern me is the level of voter participation.
For example, in the primary, about a 108,000 people voted.
This was the smallest number of people who voted in a mayor's race New Orleans in perhaps 40, maybe 50 years.
So it's competitive.
And I think what hear from people is they want the recovery of the city to be energized.
They want a sense of unification around the direction of the city.
And it's a highly competitive race.
And I think it's going to be very aggressive campaigning down to the end.
Reverend, I know that you have been addressing this specifically, the idea that you want to make sure that displaced voters have an opportunity to speak their minds.
Picking up on what Marc has said, there was a low voter turnout, but with two-thirds of the in exile, it was a really high turn out, a very enthusiastic turnout.

If the two-thirds in exile for example had satellite access and didn't have the onerous burden of drive--for example, first time voters and about 14,000 there must return to New Orleans to vote by state law.
That's an awesome burden.

If you are a resident and you live say in New York, you live in Houston or Mississippi for that matter, you must send for your ballot; it comes back to you; you then must get witnesses; a notarized affidavit; and send it back to Baton Rouge; they then take it to New Orleans.
These goings on undermine easy access.
What is interesting is that the Iraqi Americans could have onsite same day registration, seventeen forms of ID and vote in Iraq with U.S.
troops escorting them.
We do not provide the same access to New Orleans for New Orleanians, and our issue is that easy and fair access.
You believe that this really was countered to the Voting Rights Act of 1965, what we've seen here?
That's the real deal.
The Voting Rights Act of '65 was an intervention after 95 years of state's rights control for state controlled race relations and labor and education.
And the Right Wing never agreed--what we call intervention for relief they call intervention and nullification.
They never agreed.
And now that you have essentially states right federal government they suspend the enforcement of voting rights standard and threw it to the state for the first time in 41 years.
So what did the state do?
The Secretary of State will not give the voting rolls to the candidates.
So they don't know who's eligible.
They cannot write them, call them, visit them; and those who are eligible did not know who was running.

President Obama's hopes for a grand bargain on the deficit - in which Democrats would agree to rein in Medicare spending, and the GOP would agree to increase tax revenue - fell apart when House Speaker John Boehner was unable to sell the idea to his fellow Republicans.
As a result, the deal now on the table makes only incremental cuts to the deficit, all of them on the spending side.
Still, White House spokesman Jay Carney says a scaled-down version of the grand bargain could still emerge from this process.
The deal sets up a bipartisan congressional committee to find other ways to curb the deficit.
Its goal is to identify $1.5 trillion worth of savings by Thanksgiving.
And everything is on the table for that committee - entitlement reform and tax reform.
And let's be clear, the president thinks that the biggest possible overall accomplishment, in terms of deficit reduction, is a desirable goal, as long as it's balanced.
Much of the negotiation these last few days has been over what kind of stick to use to make sure the committee actually comes up with a plan, and that Congress actually passes it.
The White House was adamant that Republicans cannot use the threat of default again.

Instead, Carney says, failure by either the committee or Congress to act would trigger automatic spending cuts, including cuts to Medicare that Democrats don't want, and cuts in the Pentagon budget that Republicans don't want.
The whole purpose of a trigger is that nobody wants to pull it.
In effect, this plan relies on a 12-person committee - half Democrats, half Republicans - to make the tough decisions on deficit reduction that Congress as a whole has been unable to.
We don't have a lot of successful examples of where Congress has designed a process that, in fact, has worked.
Congressional scholar Sarah Binder, of George Washington University, says one instance where this method worked was the commission on closing unneeded military bases.
To overcome parochial interest, the base closing list was presented as a complete package, and Congress could only vote yes or no.
A similar system is planned for the deficit committee.
Binder says that would avoid the threat of a Senate filibuster or sabotage by the House Rules Committee, but only if a majority of committee members can actually come to an agreement.
Much is riding on who the Senate minority leader and the speaker appoint as their Republicans to the joint committee.
You need seven votes to report.
Let's say six Democrats lined up behind a package that includes revenues.
Would that one Republican prefer a package with revenues?
Or in fact would they prefer the pain of defense cuts?
And we can certainly see it going either way.
Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell has promised to appoint strong anti-tax members to the committee.
His Democratic counterpart, Harry Reid, said today he wants members whose deficit-reduction ideas are not set in stone.
Well, I just think we have to go into this with people with their eyes wide open, willing to make difficult choices but yet understand the political reality of the world we are in.
That reality is evolving.
Binder says if the choice comes down to increased tax revenue or decreased Pentagon spending, you could see some new cracks in the traditional Republican coalition.
Older Republican, long-term members may be more committed to defense spending than some of the newer ones, who come in clearly committed not to raising taxes.
That, again, is one of these issues that's going to raise its ugly head come winter.
Carney says the White House wants committee members who are serious about deficit reduction and about finding consensus - something that's eluded the Congress thus far.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, the White House.
A couple of years ago, a cargo ship was stolen out of a Caribbean port and taken to Haiti.
And just hours before the thieves were about to sell it on the open market, a man named Max Hardberger casually walked onboard and steered it out of port, back to its rightful owner.
Hardberger is a repo man, and he specializes in repossessing stolen cargo ships.
They actually get stolen a lot more than you think.
And in his book called ""Seized,"" Hardberger describes a life of eluding pirates and swindlers and recruiting prostitutes in disguise to help him recapture stolen ships.
Now, before Max Hardberger became known as the repo man of the seas, he taught high school English and even flew crop dusters for a stint, but he found his calling on the high seas.
And he says it's not that hard to find customers.
In fact, stealing a ship is actually pretty easy.

Well, the best way to steal a ship would be to go to some port, let's say in Venezuela, where you know a corrupt judge, or, you know, you know somebody who knows a corrupt judge, and then you just pay him to have the ship seized.
Once the ship is sold at auction, it doesn't matter if it was stolen.
It doesn't matter how it got to that auction.
The guy who buys it at the auction gets it free and clear.
So your job is to get it back.
How do you do it?
Of course, the very first thing is to vet the client.
Then I have to go on the ground and make the surveillance.
I'll find out the ship's condition.
Sometimes I'll sneak on board so that I can find out whether or not, for example, the engines can be started.
